PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
Pioneer Experiences

A word of introduction by the person submitting this questionnaire.

It is difficult to express a general statement on pioneer life because no individual has an exact idea of what pioneer life was like. However, some of the questions here will give you an opportunity to express your thoughts about pioneer life in your province or territory.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for at least ten years and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of this pioneer period whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

1. Your full name: Edwin Perrin

2. Your address: Maple Creek

3. Date: Sep. 27th 1954

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Aylesford, Kent, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): 24th March 1887

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would be under 18 at the time of your arrival)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Rail road or government information?)

"I thought my son should have a good job in the country"
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Dad objected. Rest of family said go.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   No, joined a party of emigrants in the party. I was just a nephew, Fred Hammond at Nanaimo B.C. Y.S. is all that is left of that little band.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Train, S.T. to Fondos, change to Midland to Liverpool. Shipped Aboard SS Oregon. This old tub propelled by both sail & steam & as some of the passengers said she rolled her way across.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   One incident I will remember. When on one of the fine days a bunch of us spread out back of the third house when a huge wave came over picked us up & lucky for me managed to hang on to the top rail so I'd have gone overboard, but none of course went to keep the fishes warm. A big Saloon said, do you know what to do now, go & get dry. So we went to the engine room for that purpose.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Stayed with my cousin Fred Hammond.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Right here NE28 9.25

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Worked in Woods E of the township centre of 1878-88 from there worked W. Portage La Prairie, Brandon, Whitewood, Regina & Maple Creek.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Worked on farm 6 shillings a week & at Gindal chopping cord wood 50¢ a card & board yourself. If anybody ever started at the bottom of the ladder it was yours truly.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Pov objected. Rest of family said go.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

No, I traveled with a group of friends from my hometown.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train, S.E. 16th, from Chicago to Seattle, then by boat to Vancouver.

14. What incidents of the journey have you remembered? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

One incident that stands out was when we encountered a herd of bison on the road. We had to stop our train and wait for them to pass.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Stayed with my cousins in Prince Albert.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Settled near Prince Albert.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Worked in Moose Jaw, Regina, and Prince Albert.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Worked on farms, doing odd jobs and farming at Windale. Afterward, started a small business selling goods.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Quite often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Married Ellen Palmer here on the Ranch Aug 6th 1894

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Don't remember advising anyone to come

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   My sister Christine Perin & Ellen Palmer came over on the same ship. They worked for Mrs Moffatt on the farm at Barrack, Maple Creek & married R.E. Hancock, schoolmaster. Settled on the post office at present, living retired in Maple Creek. My brother Robert came & settled here in 1898. His daughter is Mrs R.V. Perin who is at present teaching at Westport School.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Don't know whether to class it as particular. Remember my cousin Jose Hammond & I taking a stroll one day, wandered on to the Indian Reserve, which was about a mile away, met a bunch of Indians, who told us a Montana, put our feet out. So it was only a year before that a neighbour said he had seen them. Then there was the time when out on 16 mile Lake a party of us went out in Anna Blair's boat, dived in for a swim & tangled in weeds & nearly drowned. Space will not permit to relate the narrow escapes one has, such as, drowning, getting shot, being dragged by runaway horses, etc.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Not much. As it took too long riding behind a team of oxen. Last summer travelling with one person in a small car. Thought what a contrast to 67 yrs ago, going from Percival to Broadway 7 miles travelling time about 2 hrs but as Jesse had his riding we would sit in the wagon & sing hymns, to while away the time on the road. Time marches on.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
   about 1914

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Have never owned a car, too old. Most of family have cars

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   14 miles to Maple Creek

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes I believe in patronizing our home town

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   about every 2 weeks

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   In the old days if I was not home by 6 p.m. Oh I wonder what they're doing now in this age, they don't want to work till after supper. In such a rush forget half the stuff.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   First time I heard of T. Eaton was back about 1870 at that time, Barn prices being kept up in M.B. Nudels 5¢ each, & if one complained, storekeeper said it was the freight; But prices are more reasonable now.

   The reason many of the Ranch women had to patronize mail orders was they could fill out the orders at home. When on 9c of young children in some cases it would be years before a woman would get to Town.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Have no telephone

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I think anybody or most of them figured it was OK at a neighbors one time. Phone many, nothing the body of the house was kept away answering questions a long time. I said that maybe a handy thing to have. She replied yes but sometimes I feel like talking an are something it's all right sometimes, but when some gossip phones you asking a lot of stupid questions, just as you are expecting the man in for dinner it's not so good.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time, was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

I think completely or nearly. The history of the house

at a neighbor's one place. Also, I said I'd make it a

family thing. I've heard it's all something, but when one grows up

in an old community it's a lot of stupid questions. Just as you can expect,

the man in the dinner is not so good.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
Yes they did.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was chairman on the Agyleford School Board for 40 yrs.
Son John Kern is Manager Matador Community Ranch 20 yrs.
Pete is managing Director Kern Ranching Co. Bank.
Don Kernan at Nisse Plant Swift Current.

Big Bear Creek.
4 mile Coulee (Code)
